title: The Trap
descriptions:
Set in the rugged Canadian wilderness during the mid-19th century fur trade, The Trap (1966) follows the uneasy bond that forms between a grizzled, solitary trapper and a mute young woman after a harrowing incident leaves them stranded together far from civilization.

Jean “Gilles” La Bête is a powerful, taciturn fur trapper who lives by his own rules and keeps to the deep woods. When he arrives at a remote trading post, he finds the small settlement tense and precarious, dependent on the seasonal pelts and the goodwill of local Indigenous people. During his visit, a botched deal and a sudden raid throw the post into chaos. In the aftermath, with many settlers dead or fleeing and winter closing in, Gilles forces a transaction of his own: he takes Eve, a mute orphan raised by the trader’s wife, to be his companion in the wild. Terrified but with no safe alternative, Eve is taken upriver into a land of ice, forest, and roaring water.

The journey quickly becomes a test of survival. Eve, unaccustomed to the dangers of the wilderness, struggles with the canoe, the cold, and the constant threat of predators. Gilles, brusque and often rough, teaches by example and expects obedience. A violent encounter with a bear leaves Gilles gravely wounded; suddenly, the powerless Eve must become caretaker, hunter, and healer. She drags him to shelter, dresses his wounds, and learns to set snares, keep the fire, and fend off wolves. Their roles invert: the trapper lies helpless while the “captive” keeps them both alive.

In the long convalescence, a fragile understanding develops. Gilles’s ferocity softens into gruff respect as he watches Eve’s resourcefulness. Eve, initially fearful and resentful, comes to recognize the solitude that has shaped him and the harsh logic of a life lived beyond society’s rules. The vast wilderness becomes both a prison and a proving ground, forcing them to navigate not only nature’s perils—flooded rivers, starvation, and storms—but also the boundaries of trust and autonomy.

As spring thaws the forest, Gilles regains his strength. He expects life to continue as before, with Eve in his remote cabin while he runs his traplines. But the world beyond their clearing beckons. When the opportunity arises to return to the trading post region, Eve must decide whether to reclaim a tenuous place among people or remain with the man who once took her and then came to rely on her. Gilles, who rarely admits need, faces the prospect of losing the only human connection he has known in years.

The film culminates in a stark, emotional choice set against the relentless grandeur of the Canadian wilds. Without melodrama, the story explores survival, power, and the slow, uneasy birth of companionship. The “trap” of the title resonates on multiple levels: the iron snares that sustain Gilles, the circumstances that ensnare Eve, and the invisible bonds of dependence and affection that hold them both. With minimal dialogue, the narrative relies on physical action, landscape, and quiet gestures, delivering a spare yet affecting portrait of two outcasts forging a life at the edge of the world.
